The '''Demoulas family''' is a [[Greek-Americans|Greek-American]] family that controls DeMoulas Super Markets, Inc., the company that operates the [[DeMoulas Market Basket|Market Basket]] chain of supermarkets. Beginning in 1990, two sides of the Demoulas family fought for control of DeMoulas Super Markets. The dispute ended in 2014, when the family of George Demoulas sold their shares to Arthur T. Demoulas after [[Market Basket protests|protests by employees and customers]].
==Athanasios and Efrosine Demoulas== Athanasios "Arthur" Demoulas was born in 1883. He was orphaned during the [[Greco-Turkish War of 1897]].<ref name=giant /> On March 17, 1906, he arrived at [[Ellis Island]]. He settled in the Acre neighborhood of [[Lowell, Massachusetts]]. In 1914 he married Efrosene Soulis (born 1892), a girl he knew from his native village of [[Kalabaka]]. In 1917 they left their factory jobs and opened DeMoulas Market. By 1921, they had enough money to purchase a home in [[Dracut, Massachusetts]] with a slaughterhouse out back. They hoped their store would become known for its fresh lamb.<ref name="Demoulas v. Demoulas">{{cite news|last=Zernike|first=Kate|title=Demoulas v. Demoulas|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=11 January 1998}}</ref> During the [[Great Depression]], Demoulas would give families who were struggling financially a free piece of bread with ham or allow them to purchase groceries on credit.<ref name=giant />
The Demoulases had six children; John (1915–2000), George (1919–1971), an unnamed baby girl (1919–1919), Telemachus "Mike" (1920–2003), Ann (1922–), and Evangelos (1925–1930).<ref name=opinion /> In 1954, Athanasios and Efrosine Demoulas sold the market to Mike and George for $15,000.<ref name="Demoulas v. Demoulas" />
Arthur Demoulas died in 1958. Efrosene died in 1964.<ref name=family>{{cite news|last=Pereira|first=Joseph|title=Family That Amassed Supermarket Fortune Splits in a Bitter Feud|newspaper=The New York Times|date=13 July 1994}}</ref>
===John Demoulas=== John Demoulas was born on March 22, 1915. During his youth, he worked in his family's market. As an adult he ran a chain of liquor stores, a bar in Lowell (the Golden Nugget), and Marion's Cafe, also in Lowell.<ref name=John1>{{cite news|last=Macero|first=Cosmo|title=A DeMoulas steps forward, and maybe up|newspaper=Boston Herald|date=24 October 2001}}</ref><ref name=John2>{{cite book|last=DeMoulas|first=George A.|title=Illegit: A Memoir of Family Intrigue, Wealth, and Cruel Indifference|publisher=AuthorHouse|year=2014}}</ref> John Demoulas died on March 8, 2000. Demoulas had four children (John, Arthur, Pamela, and Kathleen) with his wife Marion and five illegitimate children with his mistress Dorothy Bedard (Melveen, Mike, Dorothy, George, and Patricia). In 1999, one of his illegitimate sons had his name legally changed from George Bedard to George DeMoulas.<ref name=John1 /><ref name=John2 />
==George Demoulas== George A. Demoulas was born in 1919 in [[Dracut, Massachusetts]]. He graduated from the [[Hellenic American Academy]] and [[Dracut High School]]. He served in the [[United States Army]] during [[World War II]] and was stationed at [[Guadalcanal]]. After the war, Demoulas joined the family business. In 1953, he married Evanthea Koukias. After he and his brother Mike purchased their parents' market, Demoulas served as executive vice president and treasurer of DeMoulas Super Markets, Inc. Demoulas, who was described as affable and gregarious, dealt with outside parties, including vendors.<ref name="Demoulas v. Demoulas" /><ref name=family /> He brought in many friends from the Greek community, including many people from the Acre, to do accounting, banking, and buying for the company.<ref name="Demoulas v. Demoulas" /> Within 15 years, the two brothers had transformed their parents' "mom and pop"-style store into a modern supermarket chain consisting of 15 stores.<ref name="Demoulas v. Demoulas" /><ref name=GeorgeObituary>{{cite news|title=George A. Demoulas, 51, supermarket exeuctive|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=28 June 1971}}</ref>
Demoulas was a member of the [[Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church (Lowell, Massachusetts)|Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church]] served as its president. He received the title of [[Archon Depoutatos]] from [[Patriarch Athenagoras I of Constantinople]], the highest honor that can be bestowed upon a layman by the Ecumenical Patriarchate.<ref name=GeorgeObituary />
Outside of DeMoulas Super Markets, Demoulas was a trustee of the [[Lowell Technological Institute]], [[Hellenic College Holy Cross Greek Orthodox School of Theology]], and St. John's Hospital in Lowell.<ref name=GeorgeObituary />
Demoulas died of a heart attack on June 27, 1971, while vacationing with his family in [[Athens, Greece]].<ref name=GeorgeObituary />
===Children=== George and Evanthea Demoulas had five children; Fotene (1954–), Angelo "Evan" (1955–1993), Diana (1956–), and Arthur S. (1958–).<ref name=opinion>{{cite web|url=http://masslawyersweekly.com/fulltext-opinions/1990/01/01/demoulas-v-demoulas-super-markets-inc/|title=Arthur S. Demoulas vs. DeMoulas Super Markets, Inc., & others|publisher=Massachusetts Lawyers Weekly|accessdate=10 September 2014}}</ref> Evanthea Demoulas died on February 8, 2008 in [[Westwood, Massachusetts]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Evanthea G. (Koukias) Demoulas|newspaper=The Boston Globe|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/bostonglobe/obituary.aspx?pid=103118454}}</ref>
====Evan Demoulas==== Angelo "Evan" George Demoulas was born on April 17, 1955.<ref name=DriverDB>{{cite web|url=https://www.driverdb.com/drivers/evan-demoulas/|title=Evan Demoulas|publisher=Driver Database|accessdate=7 September 2014}}</ref> He graduated from Dracut High School and attended [[Bridgton Academy]] and [[Bentley University|Bentley College]]. At Dracut High, Demoulas was a standout running back on the school's football team.<ref name=EvanObituary>{{cite news|title=Evan Demoulas, 38 Investor, race car driver|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=18 June 1993}}</ref>
Demoulas attended meat cutting school and was given a job in DeMoulas' meat department. He was also appointed to the company's Board of Directors.<ref name="Demoulas v. Demoulas" /> He eventually left the supermarket business to become a racecar driver.<ref name="Demoulas v. Demoulas" /> In 1988 he raced for [[Pacific Racing]] in [[British Formula 3 Championship|British Formula 3]].<ref name=DriverDB />
On June 13, 1993, Demoulas was in Quebec to watch the [[1993 Canadian Grand Prix|Canadian Grand Prix]]. After the race, he and his friend and former Pacific teammate [[JJ Lehto]] were driving from the [[Circuit Gilles Villeneuve|Circuit Île Notre-Dame]] to downtown [[Montreal]] when Demoulas' car was hit by a driver who had run a red light. Lehto survived, but Demoulas died at the scene.<ref>{{cite news|title=Why JJ Lehto is no stranger to tragedy|newspaper=Autosport.com|date=25 January 2011|url=http://plus.autosport.com/premium/feature/3286/why-jj-lehto-is-no-stranger-to-tragedy/}}</ref>
He was survived by his wife, Rafaele Evans Demoulas, who was pregnant with their daughter at the time.<ref name=EvanObituary />
====Arthur S. Demoulas==== Arthur Stephen Demoulas was born in 1958. During his youth, he worked for the family business. He attended the [[University of Maine]], where he was a defenseman for the [[Maine Black Bears men's ice hockey|Maine Black Bears hockey]] team.<ref name="Arthur S." /> He later transferred to [[Babson College]], where he graduated in 1984. He continued to work for DeMoulas Super Markets while in college and eventually rose to the position of assistant produce director. He left the company in 1990, as litigation between him and company president Mike Demoulas led a judge to rule that it would be best for Arthur S. to be put on paid leave. Following his family's legal victory over Mike Demoulas, Arthur S. was given a seat on the Board of Directors, but never returned to the chain's daily operations.<ref name="Arthur S.">{{cite news|last=Leung|first=Shirley|title=Out of the public eye, generosity and resolve|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=22 August 2014}}</ref>
Outside of Market Basket, Demoulas is a member of the board of the Boston Police Foundation.<ref name="Arthur S." />
==Telemachus "Mike" Demoulas== Telemachus "Mike" Demoulas was born in 1920. During his youth he was the child most involved with his parent's business. In 1938, Demoulas either dropped out or was expelled from high school and went to work for DeMoulas Market full-time. In 1954, he and his brother George purchased the business from their parents.<ref name="Demoulas v. Demoulas" /> Demoulas ran the day-to-day operations of the business and found locations for new stores.<ref name=family /> Within 15 years, the two brothers had transformed their parents' "mom and pop"-style store into a modern supermarket chain consisting of 15 stores.<ref name="Demoulas v. Demoulas" /> After his brother George's death in 1971 he expanded the Demoulas chain. He also began opening stores under different names, including Market Basket. By 1998, there were 57 Demoulas and Market Basket stores.<ref name="Demoulas v. Demoulas" /> He remained President of DeMoulas Super Markets, Inc. until 1999, when he resigned as result of a court order.<ref name=resignation>{{cite news|title= Demoulas president resigns as court order takes effect|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=7 February 1999}}</ref>
Outside of Market Basket, Demoulas was known for his philanthropy. He gave millions of dollars to many causes, including programs for the blind and college scholarships. He was credited with helping revitalize the Acre by building a new supermarket in providing money for new infrastructure.<ref name=giant>{{cite news|last=Ranalli|first=Ralph|title=Telemachus Demoulas, Supermarket Giant|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=26 May 2003}}</ref>
Demoulas died on May 24, 2003 at [[Massachusetts General Hospital]] in [[Boston]].<ref name=giant />
===Children=== In 1948, Demoulas married Irene Psoinos. Mike and Irene Demoulas had four children; Frances (1950–), Glorianne (1952–), Arthur T. (1955–), and Caren (1959–).<ref name=opinion /> Glorianne is the mother of [[National Hockey League]] forward [[Bobby Farnham]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Scott|first1=Nate|title=The Ivy Leaguer who fought his way to the NHL|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2015/01/bobby-farnham-pittsburgh-penguins-longform|accessdate=January 9, 2016|work=USA Today|date=January 15, 2015}}</ref>
====Arthur T. Demoulas==== Arthur Telemachus Demoulas was born in 1955.<ref name=opinion /> He spent his youth working in the family business. He lived in Lowell until his adolescence, when his family moved to [[Andover, Massachusetts]]. He attended [[Andover High School (Massachusetts)|Andover High School]] (where he played running back on the school's football team) and [[Bentley University|Bentley College]]. In 1974, one year after he graduated from high school, he joined DeMoulas Super Markets Board of Directors. He eventually worked his way up to the position of Vice President. In 1989, after the DeMoulas Super Markets Board of Directors rejected his proposal to start a pharmacy division, Demoulas founded Lee Drug. In 1990, he sold the chain of nine stores to [[Walgreens]].<ref name=touch /> In 1999 he resigned as Vice President as result of a court order, but remained on the Board of Directors.<ref name="resignation"/>
By 2002, Rafaele Evans, the widow of Evan Demoulas, was voting with Arthur T. Demoulas due to her displeasure with her brother-in-law, Arthur S. Demoulas, after he attempted to gain control of the trust that controlled her daughter's shares. This gave Demoulas a majority vote on the Board of Directors.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bailey|first=Steve|title=Demoulas Redux|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=23 June 2004}}</ref>
In 2008, Demoulas was named President and CEO of DeMoulas Super Markets, Inc. During his tenure as CEO, sales grew from $3 billion a year to $4 billion, the number of employees grew from 14,000 to 25,000. During the same time, competitors [[Stop & Shop]] and [[Shaw's]] closed many of their stores due to financial troubles. Market Basket also faced new competition from discount-grocer [[Wegmans]]<ref name=woman>{{cite news|last=Welker|first=Grant|title=How one woman set off the latest chapter in the Market Basket tale|newspaper=Lowell Sun|date=27 August 2014|url=http://www.sentinelandenterprise.com/news/ci_26225290/how-one-woman-set-off-latest-chapter-market#ixzz3BShqnYHn}}</ref> Arthur T. was known for his ability to remember his employees names, birthdays, and milestones, attending many of their weddings and funerals, checking in on ill workers, and asking about the spouses and children of his employees.<ref name=touch /><ref name=BBC>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-28580359 |title= Market Basket: Workers risk it all for their boss |newspaper=BBC News |last=Gittleson | first=Kim |date=1 August 2014}}</ref> He was seen as a father figure by a number of his employees and compared to ''[[It's a Wonderful Life]]'' protagonist [[George Bailey (It's a Wonderful Life)|George Bailey]] for his willingness to put people over profit.<ref name="most beloved">{{cite news |url=http://time.com/money/3024511/market-basket-ceo-demoulas-protest/ |title=Meet America’s Most Beloved CEO—Too Bad He Just Got Fired |newspaper=TIME |date=23 July 2014 |author=Tuttle, Brad |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> However, Demoulas' opponents criticized him for being "openly defiant" of the board of directors and having a "dictatorial" management style.<ref name=woman /> He was fired by the Board of Directors in June 2014, but returned to the company in August after months of protests by Market Basket employees and customers led the family of George Demoulas to sell their shares to Arthur T.<ref name=deal />
Demoulas resides in Lowell. He and his wife Maureen have three daughters; Madeline, Irene, Mary and; one son Telemachus Arthur <ref name=touch />
==Legal disputes== In October 1989, Evan Demoulas was notified that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts was seeking back taxes on $1 million worth of stock he had sold three years earlier. Demoulas was confused by the call, as he had never sold any stock. He investigated and found that his uncle, Mike Demoulas, had purchased much of his and his family's shares in Demoulas Super Markets without their knowledge.<ref name=family />
In 1990, the widow and children of George Demoulas sued Mike Demoulas, alleging that they had been defrauded out of their shares in the company. They claimed they had trusted Mike to take care of the family after George's death and that he exploited this trust in order to have them sell all of George's real estate and 84% of his shares in DeMoulas Super Markets to members of his own family pennies on the dollar.<ref name="Demoulas v. Demoulas" /> Mike Demoulas contended that his brother's heirs had willingly sold their shares in the company because they wanted money and their stock in DeMoulas did not pay dividends. According to Mike Demoulas, Evanthea, asked him to sell her shares so she could have money to raise her children, Evan sold his shares so he could begin his auto racing career, and Diana and Fotene sold their shares after the saw how much money their brother received. However, once the company began paying dividends in 1988, the family saw how much money they could have made if they had kept their shares and sought to "rewrite history" in order to regain what they had sold. George's children acknowledged that they had signed many of the documents authorizing the sales and transfers, but stated they were not aware of what they were signing because they were too young to understand and trusted their uncle to take care of them. A jury found in favor of George's family.<ref name="Demoulas v. Demoulas" /><ref name=Zealousness>{{cite journal|last=Frisch|first=Michael S.|title=Zealousness Run Amok|journal=The Georgetown Journal of Legal Ethics|date=Fall 2007}}</ref>
A few weeks after the decision, George's son Arthur S. Demoulas filed a second suit, this time alleging that Mike Demoulas had diverted assets from the jointly-owned family company, Demoulas Super Markets, to ones controlled by him and his children, including Market Basket. After an eighty-four-day bench trial, judge [[Maria Lopez]] found in favor of the plaintiffs. Lopez awarded George's family about $206 million for dividends on stock that had been improperly diverted and 50.5% of the company. She also ordered that all of the assets of Market Basket and the other companies controlled by Mike Demoulas and his family be transferred to Demoulas Super Markets and that Mike Demoulas be removed as president of the company.<ref name=Zealousness /><ref name=wiretap>{{cite news|last=Nealon|first=Patricia|title=Wiretap claims are key to DeMoulas fight|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=16 July 1997}}</ref>
In early September 1990, six [[Covert listening device|bugs]] were found at the headquarters of DeMoulas Super Markets. It was alleged that Arthur S. Demoulas had planted the bugs in order to listen to the legal strategy of the other side of the Demoulas family. Michael Kettenbach, the son-in law of Mike Demoulas, sued Arthur S. Demoulas, claiming that Demoulas had "invaded his privacy rights by having listening devices planted at DSM headquarters." In 1994, a jury found in favor of Arthur S. Demoulas.<ref name=Zealousness /><ref name=wiretap /> However, a new trial was granted after a woman came forward with new evidence – a recording of her boyfriend admitting to bugging the office for Arthur S. Demoulas. The case was damaged though when the woman admitted to being a crack cocaine addict who received about $500,000 in housing and other expenses from the family of Telemachus Demoulas and the man on the tape testified that he had been lying during the recorded conversation. On August 4, 1997, Arthur S. Demoulas was again cleared of wiretapping charges by a federal jury.<ref name=Zealousness /><ref name=Zealousness /><ref>{{cite news|last=Nealon|first=Patricia|title=Federal court jury clears Demoulas|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=5 August 1997}}</ref>
In 1991, George Demoulas' family sued Mike Demoulas, Arthur T. Demoulas, and DeMoulas Super Markets, Inc. chief financial officer D. Harold Sullivan, alleging that the three violated the [[Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974]] by using their positions as the trustees of the company's employee profit-sharing plan to make fiscally irresponsible real estate loans to friends and business associates.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kennedy|first=John H.|title=Demoulas family in another legal squabble|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=16 October 1991}}</ref> The [[United States Department of Labor]] filed a similar complaint six months later.<ref>{{cite news|last=Zuckoff|first=Mitchell|title=Labor Dept. Joins Demoulas Family Fight|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=13 June 1992}}</ref> On May 31, 1994 the Department of Labor announced that they had reached a settlement in which the trustees agreed to sell $22 million of the loans by July 11 or purchase them themselves as well as pay the plan $750,000 to make up for the dropped interest rates on the loans (unless the loan recipients paid the money instead). The trustees also agreed not to make any similar investments. The trustees admitted no wrongdoing in the case.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kennedy|first=John H.|title=Demoulas pension plan suit is settled|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=1 June 1994}}</ref> Despite the heavy investment in risky real estate loans, the plan never posted a loss. In the civil case, Judge [[Rya W. Zobel]] ruled that the trustees' actions were "wrong but not corrupt" and that the settlement with the Department of Labor was "an adequate remedy". Therefore, she denied the request to have them removed.<ref>{{cite news|last=Reidy|first=Chris|title=Pension trustees cleared|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=14 April 1995}}</ref>
In 1997, the [[Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court]] upheld a lower court's ruling that Arthur T. Demoulas had presented the DeMoulas Super Markets Board of Directors with “misleading, inaccurate, and materially incomplete” information in order to receive a rejection and keep his cousins from receiving any of the profits from Lee Drug, a pharmacy chain he started after the board rejected his proposal to start a pharmacy division of Market Basket.<ref name=touch>{{cite news|last=Borchers|first=Callum|title=Arthur T. Demoulas’s personal touch can cut both ways|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=22 August 2014|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2014/08/21/arthur-demoulas-profile-personal-touch-that-can-cut-two-ways/IqkmJ1i7A4AFKpLenN8vBM/story.html}}</ref>
[[File:Market Basket at the Cape Cod Factory Outlet Mall.JPG|thumb|Market Basket store in Bourne]] In a 2010 memo to the Board of Directors, Arthur S. Demoulas accused Arthur T. Demoulas of "plundering" millions by paying millions in excessive real estate prices for new Market Basket store locations. One example cited in the memo alleged that Arthur T. had recommended that the company pay $20.9 million to purchase a property in [[Bourne, Massachusetts]] owned by an entity in which he was a major investor. After the sale, Arthur S. had the property appraised by a Boston real estate executive, who valued the property at $9 million. He also accused Arthur T. of paying "grossly excessive fees" to Retail Development and Management Inc., a real estate firmed owned by his brothers-in-law Michael Kettenbach and Joseph Pasquale that oversaw Market Basket's real estate and helped it develop new stores. He and his attorneys argued that the 7.5% of the total development costs "was far in excess" of the prevailing market rate of 2% to 3%.<ref name=memos>{{cite news|last=Ross|first=Casey|title= Legal memos trace acrimony between Demoulas factions|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=2 August 2014|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2014/08/01/legal-memos-trace-acrimony-between-demoulas-factions-over-real-estate-deals/FPXxU0sANyOcyzmpzjISmO/story.html}}</ref> Arthur T. denied his cousin's claim. He argued that Arthur S. trumped up the charges in order to take control of the company and pay himself and the other shareholders more money. Attorneys for Arthur T. noted that [[Cushman & Wakefield]] later appraised the Bourne property at $25.5 million. Arthur T. also defended his arrangement with Kettenbach and Pasquale, which he said allowed Market Basket to purchase properties without alerting its competitors, thus avoiding a bidding war and saving the company money.<ref name=memos /> The Board of Directors hired Mel L. Greenberg, a retired judge, to investigate Arthur S.' claims. Greenberg found that there was no wrongdoing by Arthur T. in the purchase of real estate (including the Bourne property) that the fees paid to Retail Development and Management were not excessive. However, he did find that Arthur T. and the Board of Directors had neglected their fiduciary duties by not looking into whether or not the company would have been better off if it had exercised its option to purchase its store in [[Somersworth, New Hampshire]] instead of renting it from a company in which Arthur T. and his family owned a 55% stake.<ref name=memos />
==Firing of Arthur T. Demoulas, protests, and sale of shares== {{main|Market Basket protests}} In mid-2013, Rafaele Evans switched loyalties, which tipped the majority vote from Arthur T. to Arthur S.<ref name=woman /><ref name=heck>{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/business/news/2014/07/21/what-just-happened-market-basket-this-weekend/vZc828jbvG5lak5CHtd6yM/story.html |title=Updated: What the Heck Is Happening at Market Basket? |newspaper=Boston Globe |author=Vaccaro, Adam |date=25 August 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826002851/http://www.boston.com/business/news/2014/07/21/what-just-happened-market-basket-this-weekend/vZc828jbvG5lak5CHtd6yM/story.html |archivedate=26 August 2014}}<!--update permalink when citing new information--></ref>
On June 23, 2014, Arthur T. Demoulas was fired by the Board of Directors.<ref name="Market Basket CEO canned">{{cite web|last1=Scott|first1=Christopher|title=Market Basket CEO canned|url=http://www.lowellsun.com/news/ci_26022535/market-basket-ceo-canned|website=Lowell Sun|accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref> In response to his firing, six high-level managers resigned, and 300 employees held a rally outside Market Basket's [[Chelsea, Massachusetts]] flagship store on June 24.<ref name="leaders resign">{{cite web |last1=Vaccaro |first1=Adam |title=Leaders Resign While Hundreds of Market Basket Employees Rally in Support of Fired CEO |url=http://www.boston.com/business/news/2014/06/24/leaders-resign-while-hundreds-market-basket-employees-rally-support-fired-ceo/9zCZ2UpaoJnyliVAfEjD7H/story.html |website=Boston Globe |date=24 June 2014 |accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> Beginning on July 18, 300 warehouse workers and 68 drivers refused to make deliveries, which left store shelves severely depleted.<ref name="Seriously Consider">{{cite news|title=Market Basket Board Will ‘Seriously Consider’ Ex-CEO Proposal To Buy Chain |newspaper=WBUR |date=25 July 2014 |url=http://www.wbur.org/2014/07/25/market-basket-final-rallyl |df= }}{{dead link|date=April 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> On August 27, 2014, after months of protest by Market Basket employees and customers, the shareholders of DeMoulas Super Markets, Inc. reached an agreement to sell the remaining 50.5% shares of the company to Arthur T. Demoulas for $1.5 billion.<ref name=deal>{{cite news|url=http://www.wcvb.com/news/source-deal-reached-to-sell-market-basket-to-arthur-t-demoulas/27764382?tru=bLunoe#comments |title=Deal reached to sell Market Basket to Arthur T. Demoulas|newspaper=WCVB.com|date=27 August 2014 |accessdate=27 August 2014}}</ref>
==Wealth== In July 2014, ''[[Forbes]]'' estimated the Demoulas family's net worth to be $2.2 billion. They also ranked the family as the 104th richest family in the United States. The following year, Forbes put their value at $3.3 Billion, which made them the 83rd richest family in the U.S. The Demoulas family dropped off the ''Forbes'' list in 2016.<ref>{{cite news|title=#104 Demoulas family|newspaper=Forbes|date=July 2015|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/demoulas/}}</ref>

{{Infobox person |name = Dianna Booher |image = |image_size = |alt = Dianna Booher |caption = Dianna Booher |birth_place = Hillsboro, Texas |residence = [[Colleyville]], [[Texas]] |nationality = [[United States|American]] |known_for = |education = [[Master of Arts]], English |alma_mater = [[University of Houston]] |employer = |occupation = [[Author]]
[[Consultant]]
[[Keynote speaker]] |home_town = Hillsboro, Texas |website = {{URL|booherresearch.com}} }} '''Dianna Booher''' is an [[United States|American]] [[author]],{{cite web | url=https://nypost.com/2009/12/06/freeman-almighty/ | title=Freeman almighty | publisher=[[New York Post]] | date=6 December 2009 | accessdate=11 December 2014 | author=Tucker, Reed}} and communication expert.{{cite web | url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/jobcenter/workplace/bruzzese/story/2011-11-09/how-to-position-yourself-to-get-ahead/51132836/1 | title=Appearance, body language make a difference to your boss | publisher=[[USA Today]] | date=9 November 2011 | accessdate=11 December 2014 | author=Bruzzese, Anita}} She is also the chief executive of ''Booher Research Institute'',{{Cite web|title = Home|url = http://www.booherresearch.com|website = Booher Research Institute|accessdate = 2015-10-28}} a Colleyville, Texas-based company that offers communication consulting, executive coaching (public speaking, executive presence, enterprise-wide communication messaging), and publishing strategies for Fortune 500 organizations and nonprofit organizations.{{Cite web|title = About Booher Research|url = http://www.booherresearch.com/about/booher-research/|website = Booher Research Institute|accessdate = 2015-10-28}} She is also the founder of Booher Consultants, a communication training firm, that has worked for [[Fortune 500]] organizations and governmental agencies since 1980. Booher Consultants was acquired by Communispond on August 1, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.prunderground.com/communispond-acquires-booher-consultants/0099853/|title=Communispond Acquires Booher Consultants|publisher=|accessdate=20 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/how-leaders-cripple-their-teams-with-these-5-mistakes_us_5943d259e4b024b7e0df4afe|title=How Leaders Cripple Their Teams With 5 Mistakes|first=Dianna Booher, MA, Speaker Hall of|last=Fame|date=16 June 2017|publisher=|accessdate=20 October 2017}} ==Early life and education== Dianna Daniels Booher was born in [[Hillsboro, Texas]], as the daughter of a postal supervisor Alton B. and Opal Daniels. She graduated ''[[Latin honors|cum laude]]'' from North [[Texas State University]] in 1970 with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] and earned a Master of Arts degree in [[English literature]] from [[University of Houston]] in 1979.{{cite web | url=http://bureau.espeakers.com/nsas/speaker.php?sid=5147&showreturntoresults=true | title=Dianna Booher, MA, CSP, CPAE | publisher=[[National Speakers Association]] | accessdate=3 December 2014}} In 1967 she married Daniel T. Booher, a minister of music. They had two children: Jeffrey Thomas and Lisa Christine.{{cite book | url=https://docs.google.com/file/d/13AoJJlGjTQL7jfvZzDw3t4zvrVJkKmfmBtGVsyaKt-I1I0RkO8RAdNb_rA9X/edit | title=Contemporary Authors | publisher=Gale | author=M Rooney, Terrie | year=1998 | pages=50–51 | isbn=9780787619985}} ==Publications== Booher has written 47 books on business and personal development topics, all published by major U.S. publishers and their various imprints: Simon and Schuster, Penguin Random House, McGraw-Hill, and HarperCollins.{{Cite web|title = About Dianna Booher – Communication Strategies for Leaders™|url = http://www.booherresearch.com/about/dianna-booher-communication-strategies-leaders/|website = Booher Research Institute|accessdate = 2015-10-28}}{{cite web|url=http://www.booherresearch.com/books/|title=Books by Dianna Booher|first=Dianna|last=Booher|website=www.booherresearch.com|accessdate=20 October 2017}} Reviewing ''Your Signature Work'', ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' criticized its use of a "hackneyed analogy" between life and basketball, but said it offers "good advice".{{cite web|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-8423-8281-6|title=Religion Book Review: Your Signature Work: Creating Excellence and Influencing Others at Work by Dianna Booher, Author Tyndale House Publishers $12.99 (225p) ISBN 978-0-8423-8281-6|publisher=|accessdate=20 October 2017}} [[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]] called ''E-Writing'' "user-friendly" in a favorable review.{{cite web|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20010416&slug=bizbook16X|title=Business & Technology - Book reviews: Money doesn't govern the world, author says - Seattle Times Newspaper|website=community.seattletimes.nwsource.com|accessdate=20 October 2017}} Her 2015 book, ''What More Can I Say? Why Communication Fails and What to Do About It'', is discussed in articles in Forbes, FastCompany.com,{{cite web|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3040332/9-reasons-leaders-fail-to-communicate-and-what-to-do-about-it|title=9 Reasons Communication Fails - Fast Company|date=5 January 2015|publisher=|accessdate=20 October 2017}} TLNT.com, and Huffington Post.{{Cite web|title = Recent Media & Dianna Booher in the News|url = http://www.booherresearch.com/newsroom/recent-media-dianna-booher-in-the-news/|website = Booher Research Institute|accessdate = 2015-10-28}} Her 2017 book ''Communicate Like a Leader: Connecting Strategically to Coach, Inspire, and Get Things Done'' was mentioned favorably in INC, Entrepreneur.com, and Forbes.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/womensmedia/2017/05/10/how-to-communicate-like-a-confident-leader/#b6192a64a3ea|title=How To Communicate Like A Confident Leader|first=|last=WomensMedia|publisher=|accessdate=20 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/more-on-the-power-pose-1393374979|title=More on the Power Pose|date=26 February 2014|publisher=|accessdate=20 October 2017|via=www.wsj.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/290535|title=How Every Entrepreneur Has Seemingly|first=Jennifer|last=Miller|date=29 March 2017|publisher=|accessdate=20 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rd.com/health/wellness/stop-being-socially-awkward/1/|title=How to Stop Being Socially Awkward - Reader's Digest|publisher=|accessdate=20 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.inc.com/martin-zwilling/7-bad-habits-that-will-demoralize-your-team-and-how-to-fix-them.html|title=7 Leadership Habits That Are Demoralizing Your Team Without You Realizing It|publisher=|accessdate=20 October 2017}} ==Selected Bibliography== * ''Communicate Like a Leader: Connecting Strategically to Coach, Inspire, and Get Things Done'' (Berrett-Koehler) * ''What MORE Can I Say? Why Communication Fails and What to Do About It'' (Penguin Random House/Perigee) * ''Communicate With Confidence: How to Say It Right the First Time and Every Time'' (Revised and Expanded Edition) (McGraw-Hill) * ''Creating Personal Presence: How to Look, Talk, Think, and Act Like a Leader'' (Berrett-Koehler) * ''The Voice of Authority: 10 Communication Strategies Every Leader Needs to Know'' (McGraw-Hill) * ''Booher’s Rules of Business Grammar: 101 Fast and Easy Ways to Correct the Most Common Errors'' (McGraw-Hill) * ''Your Signature Work: Creating Excellence and Influencing Others at Work'' (Tyndale) * ''Speak With Confidence: Powerful Presentations That Inform, Inspire, and Persuade'' (McGraw-Hill) * ''E-Writing: 21st Century Tools for Effective Communication'' (Simon and Schuster/Pocket Books) == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.booherresearch.com}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Booher, Dianna}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:American self-help writers]] [[Category:University of Houston alumni]] [[Category:People from Hillsboro, Texas]] [[Category:People from Colleyville, Texas]] [[Category:American women non-fiction writers]]

{{Orphan|date=August 2017}}
'''Disagree and commit''' is a management principle which states that individuals are allowed to disagree while a decision is being made, but that once a decision has been made, everybody must commit to it. The principle can also be understood as a statement about ''when'' it is useful to have conflict and disagreement, with the principle saying disagreement is useful in early states of [[decision-making]] while harmful after a decision has been made.<ref name="Origbo">{{cite web | url = https://seekingmastery.wordpress.com/2017/05/29/make-disagree-and-commit-work-for-you/ | title = Make "Disagree and Commit" Work for You | website = Seeking Mastery | publisher = WordPress.com | first = Efesa | last = Origbo | date = May 29, 2017 | accessdate = July 2, 2017}}</ref> Disagree and commit is a method of avoiding the consensus trap, in which the lack of consensus leads to inaction.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://encyclopedia.uia.org/en/problem/140262 | title = Consensus trap {{!}} World Problems & Global Issues | publisher = ''[[Encyclopedia of World Problems and Human Potential|The Encyclopedia of World Problems]]'' | accessdate = July 3, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Cj9s1QihGPIC&lpg=PP1&pg=PT45#v=onepage&q&f=false | title = The Advantage: Why Organizational Health Trumps Everything Else in Business | first = Patrick | last = Lencioni | date = March 14, 2012 | publisher = John Wiley & Sons | quote = Great teams avoid the consensus trap by embracing a concept that Intel, the legendary microchip manufacturer, calls "disagree and commit." Basically they believe that even when people can't come to an agreement around an issue, they must still leave the room umambiguously committed to a common course of action.| isbn = 9781118266106 }}</ref>
==History==
[[Scott McNealy]] used the phrase as early as sometime between 1983 and 1991, as part of the line "Agree and commit, disagree and commit, or get out of the way".<ref>{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=rQl4169IA4kC&lpg=PA39&dq=disagree%20and%20commit%20scott%20mcnealy&pg=PA39#v=onepage&q=disagree%20and%20commit%20scott%20mcnealy&f=false | title = High Noon: The Inside Story of Scott McNealy and the Rise of Sun Microsystems | first = Karen | last = Southwick | year = 1999 | publisher = John Wiley & Sons, Inc.| isbn = 9780471297130 }}</ref>{{rp|39}}<ref name="Origbo" /><ref>{{cite web | url = https://ecorner.stanford.edu/1642.ect | title = Agree and Commit, Disagree and Commit | first = Greg | last = Ballard | date = November 15, 2006 | publisher = Stanford eCorner | quote = This is a phrase, agree and commit, disagree and commit, that actually comes from Scott McNealy. At least that's where I was told it was from.}}</ref>
The concept has also been attributed to [[Andrew Grove]] at [[Intel]].<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.inc.com/magazine/201412/patrick-lencioni/innovation-wont-get-you-very-far.html | title = Why Great Leadership Fuels Innovation | date = November 20, 2014 | publisher = Inc.com | first = Patrick | last = Lencioni | accessdate = July 2, 2017 | quote = At Intel, Grove demanded not only that his people argue well, but also that they leave those argument-rich meetings fully committed to the decisions that had been made. His famous axiom "disagree and commit" captures an essential truth: Failure to capitalize on a new idea often has far less to do with the quality of the idea than with the indecision and waffling that accompany it.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=AdqIP5GN4GQC&lpg=PA140&vq=disagree%20and%20commit&pg=PA112#v=onepage&q&f=false | title = Absolute Honesty: Building a Corporate Culture that values Straight Talk and Rewards Integrity |first1=Larry |last1=Johnson |first2=Bob |last2=Phillips | year = 2003 | publisher = AMACOM| isbn = 9780814407813 }}</ref>{{rp|112}}<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/monika-szamko/what-the-paranoid-got-rig_b_9612326.html | title = What the Paranoid Got Right – The Unlikely Legacy of Andy Grove's Intel | publisher = [[The Huffington Post]] | first = Monika | last = Szamko | date = April 5, 2016 | accessdate = July 2, 2017}}</ref>
[[Amazon.com|Amazon]] added "Have a Backbone; Disagree and Commit" as one of its leadership principles sometime in 2010–2011.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.amazon.com/Values-Careers-Homepage/b?ie=UTF8&node=239365011 | title = Amazon.com: Amazon Values | deadurl = bot: unknown | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110522092317/http://www.amazon.com/Values-Careers-Homepage/b?ie=UTF8&node=239365011 | archivedate = 2011-05-22 | df = }}</ref> Amazon CEO [[Jeff Bezos]] mentioned the term in his "2016 Letter to Shareholders".<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.amazon.com/p/feature/z6o9g6sysxur57t | title = About Amazon - 2016 Letter to Shareholders | accessdate = July 2, 2017 | date = April 12, 2017}}</ref>
==Organizations that have used the principle==
* [[Sun Microsystems]] * [[Intel]]<ref>{{cite web | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=5QkAAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA72&ots=wL6hn2E3Hg&dq=%22disagree%20and%20commit%22%20intel&pg=PA72#v=onepage&q&f=false | title = High Technology, High Pressure | first = Howard | last = Baldwin | date = December 1, 1998 | publisher = ''[[CIO magazine]]''}}</ref>{{rp|72}}<ref>{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/?id=b1uwZORz2w8C&lpg=PT228&dq=%22disagree%20and%20commit%22%20intel&pg=PT228#v=onepage&q=%22disagree%20and%20commit%22%20intel&f=false | title = Agile Project Management | first = Jim | last = Highsmith | date = April 6, 2004 | publisher = Pearson Education| isbn = 9780321630025 }}</ref> * [[Amazon.com]]<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2017/04/13/jeff-bezos-amazon-annual-shareholder-letter-day-1/100418722/ | publisher = [[USA Today]] | title = Amazon's Jeff Bezos urges employees to 'disagree and commit' | accessdate = July 2, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.amazon.com/p/feature/p34qgjcv93n37yd | title = About Amazon - Working at Amazon - Our Leadership Principles | publisher = Amazon | accessdate = July 2, 2017 | quote = Have Backbone; Disagree and Commit Leaders are obligated to respectfully challenge decisions when they disagree, even when doing so is uncomfortable or exhausting. Leaders have conviction and are tenacious. They do not compromise for the sake of social cohesion. Once a decision is determined, they commit wholly.}}</ref> * [[GitLab]]<ref>{{cite web | url = https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/values/ | publisher = GitLab | title = GitLab Values | accessdate = July 2, 2017 | quote = Disagree and commit Everything can be questioned but as long as a decision is in place we expect people to commit to executing it, which is a common principle.}}</ref> * [[Chef (software)|Chef Software]]<ref>{{cite web | url = https://github.com/chef/sdlc-facilitators-guide/blob/master/notes.md#chef-engineering-mission-and-beliefs | publisher = GitHub | title = chef/sdlc-facilitators-guide | accessdate = July 3, 2017 | quote = We disagree and commit}}</ref>
==Reception==
Noted difficulties of applying "disagree and commit" are:<ref name="Origbo" />
* It can be difficult to disagree with more powerful or senior individuals * There can be [[Cognitive dissonance|dissonance]] in committing to something while being unconvinced of it
