{{Infobox information appliance | name = Family Computer Network System | title = | aka = | logo = | logo_alt = | image = [[File:Nintendo-Famicom-Modem-Network-System-Attached.jpg|250px]] | image_alt = The Famicom Modem | caption = Famicom with modem | developer = [[Nintendo]] | manufacturer = | family = | type = [[modem]] [[Video game accessory|peripheral]] | generation = [[History of video game consoles (third generation)|Third generation]] | releasedate = {{vgrelease|JP|September 1988}} | lifespan = 3 years | price = | discontinued = {{vgrelease|JP|{{end date|2001}}}} | unitssold = | unitsshipped = 130,000<ref name="How the Famicom Modem was Born"/> | media = [[ROM cartridge|ROM]] card | os = | power = | soc = | cpu = | memory = | storage = | Removable storage =[[ROM]] card | display = | graphics = | sound = | input = | controllers = | camera = | touchpad = | connectivity =dialup modem | platform = | service = [[Nomura Securities]] | dimensions = | weight = | topgame = | compatibility= | predecessor = | successor = | related = [[Famicom]] | website = }}
The {{nihongo|'''Family Computer Network System'''|ファミリーコンピュータ ネットワークシステム|Famirī Konpyūta Nettowāku Shisutemu|lead=yes}}, also known as the '''Famicom Net System''' or '''Famicom Modem''', is a video game peripheral for Nintendo's [[Nintendo Entertainment System|Family Computer]], released in September 1988 only in Japan. It uses a card based format, reminiscent to the [[HuCard]] for [[Hudson Soft]]'s and [[NEC]]'s [[TurboGrafx-16|PC Engine]] or the [[Sega Card]] for the [[Master System]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ne.jp/asahi/oroti/famicom/ish11.html |title=ファミコンの周辺機器が大集合! ザ☆周辺機器ズ 11 |publisher=Ne.jp |date= |accessdate=2014-06-14}}</ref><ref>''[http://www.famitsu.com/game/news/2006/03/25/103,1143298259,50588,0,0.html Wi-Fiコネクションについて講演 『ウイイレ』など40タイトルが開発中]''. [[Famitsu]]. 25 March 2006.</ref> It allowed the user access to a server that provided live stock trades, [[cheating in video games|game cheats]], jokes, weather forecasts, horse betting, and a small amount of downloadable content.<ref name="How the Famicom Modem was Born">{{ cite magazine | first=Masaharu | last=Takano | title=How the Famicom Modem was Born | others=[http://www.glitterberri.com/developer-interviews/how-the-famicom-was-born/developing-the-famicom-modem/ English translation by GlitterBerri] | date=September 11, 1995 | magazine=Nikkei Electronics | language=Japanese }}</ref>
The experience Nintendo gained with this endeavor led directly to the deployment of the satellite based [[Satellaview]] network for the [[Super Famicom]] in the early 1990s. Nintendo would eventually engage in Internet based networking, via the [[64DD]] and its accompanying Randnet service, the [[Nintendo GameCube|GameCube]], the [[Nintendo GameCube–Game Boy Advance cable|Game Boy Advance Cable]], the Nintendo DS's DS Download Play, the Wii's [[WiiConnect24]] and its shop, the [[Nintendo DSi]]'s DSi Shop, and the [[Nintendo Network]] for the [[Nintendo 3DS]], [[Wii U]], and [[Nintendo Switch | Switch]].
==History== ===Development=== Beginning in mid-1987, Nintendo president Hiroshi Yamauchi requested the exploration of a partnership with the [[Nomura Securities]] financial company, to create an information network service in Japan based on the Famicom. Led by Masayuki Uemura, [[Nintendo Research & Development 2]] developed the modem hardware; and Nomura Securities developed the client and server software and the information database. Uemura cautioned that they "weren't confident that they would be able to make network games entertaining". Five unreleased prototypes of network-enabled games were developed for the system, including Yamauchi's favorite classic, [[Go (game)|Go]].<ref name="How the Famicom Modem was Born"/>
===Production=== [[File:Nintendo-Famicom-Modem-Network-System-04.jpg|thumb|right|The telephone line connectors on the bottom of the modem.]] [[File:Nintendo-Famicom-Modem-Controller.jpg|thumb|right|The controller included with the modem.]] The Famicom Modem began mass production in September 1988. The accompanying proprietary online service was soon launched the same year alongside [[Nippon Telegraph and Telephone]]'s new DDX-TP telephone gateway for its existing packet switched network. NTT's launch initially suffered reliability problems that were painstakingly assessed by Nintendo at individual users' homes and traced back to the network.<ref name="How the Famicom Modem was Born"/>
Nintendo's sole final application of the Famicom Modem was the 1991 system called Super Mario Club. It was formed for toy shops, where the Famicom was deployed as a networked arcade kiosk, serving consumers with a member-store-created searchable online database of Famicom game reviews. Nintendo performed market research by analyzing users' search behaviors, and directly received user feedback messages.<ref name="How the Famicom Modem was Born"/>
In June 1989, Nintendo of America's vice president of marketing Peter Main, said that the Famicom was present in 37% of Japan's households and that its interactive game and stock network based upon the Famicom Modem had been running for some time.<ref name="How Nintendo Can Help A.T.&T">{{cite news | newspaper=International New York Times | issn=0362-4331 | title=Talking Deals; How Nintendo Can Help A.T.&T. | first=Michael | last=Freitag | date=June 8, 1989 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/08/business/talking-deals-how-nintendo-can-help-at-t.html | accessdate=February 7, 2015}}</ref>
==Reception== [[File:Nintendo-Famicom-Modem-Network-System-Horse-Betting.jpg|thumb|right|The software card for the horse betting program.]] Nintendo shipped a lifetime total of 130,000 Famicom Modems. Even after the resolution of stability problems with the NTT's network launch, the Famicom Modem market presence was considered "weak" for its whole lifetime for various reasons: product usability; competition from personal computers and other appliances; and the difficult nature of early adoption by the technologically unsavvy financial customer. Uemura stated that the system's most popular application was ultimately home-based horse race betting, with a peak of 100,000 units used and capturing 35% of the online horse betting market even amongst diverse competition from PCs and from dedicated horse betting network terminal appliances.<ref name="How the Famicom Modem was Born"/>
===Legacy=== Wanting to replicate and expand upon the progress seen with the Famicom Modem in Japan, Nintendo of America began a series of open announcements in mid-1989 to describe its private talks with AT&T over the prospect of launching an information network service in America in 1990.<ref name="How Nintendo Can Help A.T.&T"/> The plans never materialized.
A modem for NES was tested in the United States by the [[Minnesota State Lottery]]. It would have allowed players to buy [[scratchcard]]s and play the lottery with their NES at home. It was not released in the United States because some parents and legislators voiced concern that minors might learn to play the lottery illegally and anonymously, regardless of assurances from Nintendo to the contrary.<ref name="lottery">{{cite news |title= Nintendo and Minnesota Set A Living-Room Lottery Test|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/27/business/nintendo-and-minnesota-set-a-living-room-lottery-test.html|accessdate=2008-02-16|date =1991-09-27|work=New York Times | first=Eben | last=Shapiro}}</ref> Internet-based gambling was banned in Minnesota.<ref name="Minnesota Gambling and Criminal Defense">{{cite web | title=Minnesota Gambling and Criminal Defense | url=http://www.nvo.com/beaulier/minnesotagamblingcrimes/ | accessdate=February 7, 2015}}</ref>
Online content would later be delivered to Nintendo's customers via the [[Super Famicom]]'s [[Satellaview]] peripheral. Masayuki Uemura, lead designer of the Famicom Modem at [[Nintendo Research & Development 2]], said: "Our experiences with the Famicom Modem triggered Nintendo’s entrance into the satellite data broadcasting market in April, 1995".<ref name="How the Famicom Modem was Born"/>

{{EngvarB|date=January 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Gavin Patterson | image = Gavin Patterson at Chatham House 2016.jpg | image_size = | caption = Patterson speaking at [[Chatham House]] in 2016 | birth_name = Gavin Echlin Patterson | birth_date = {{bda|1967|09|06|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Altrincham]], England | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | nationality = British | residence = Surrey, England | education = | alma mater = [[Emmanuel College, Cambridge]] | occupation = Businessman | title = CEO, [[BT Group plc]] | term = September 2013 - December 2018 | predecessor = [[Ian Livingston]] | successor = [[Philip Jansen]] | known for = | boards = | salary = | networth = | spouse = Karen | children = 4 | parents = | relations = | website = }}
'''Gavin Echlin Patterson'''<!-- Bloomberg uses initial, no-one else seems to: have added a redirect from that form --> (born 6 September 1967) is a British [[marketer]] who was appointed chief executive of [[BT Group plc]] in September 2013. Before joining BT, he worked for [[Telewest]] and [[Procter & Gamble]]. He is the president of the [[Advertising Association]]. Patterson will leave his role as CEO of BT at the end of 2018.
==Early life == He was born in [[Altrincham]] in 1967, and attended schools in [[Warrington]] and [[Yeovil]].<ref name=guardianprofile/><ref name=BD>{{citation |url=http://www.thebusinessdesk.com/northwest/news/481651-altrincham-born-patterson-to-lead-bt.html# |title=Altrincham-born Patterson to lead BT |date=20 June 2013 |author=Chris Barry |publisher=The Business Desk}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/mediatechnologyandtelecoms/7005740/BTs-Gavin-Patterson-Skys-football-claims-dont-wash-with-me.html |journal=[[Daily Telegraph]] |title=BT's Gavin Patterson: Sky's football claims don't wash with me |author=Rupert Neate |date=16 January 2010}}</ref> He graduated from [[Emmanuel College, Cambridge]] with a bachelor's degree in [[chemical engineering]].<ref name=guardianprofile>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/nov/11/gavin-patterson-bt-sport-champions-league |title=Gavin Patterson: the man behind BT Sport's Champions League raid |last=Gibson |first=Owen |date=11 November 2013 |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=3 January 2014}}</ref>
==Career== He was European head of marketing at [[Procter & Gamble]] for their [[Pantene]] line of hair products.<ref name=FT/> In 2000, he joined the cable company [[Telewest]], managing their television services. In 2004, he moved to BT to be the managing director of their consumer division. He launched [[BT Vision]] which provided on-demand TV and subsequently was responsible for their broadband offerings such as the optical fibre service, [[BT Infinity]].<ref name=FT/> At BT, his management style was a mix of relaxed, stylish marketing with aggressive cost-cutting. He was known for his flamboyant appearance of romantic black hair and open shirt collars.<ref name=FT/> The previous chief executive, [[Ian Livingston]], said of him, "...one button undone was fine, two was a bit racy, and three was Gavin."<ref name=FT/> This marketing-executive style was novel and successful in the conservative corporate culture of BT and, as a high-flyer, he joined the board of BT in 2008.<ref name=guardianprofile/><ref name=FT/>
===BT=== He was appointed chief executive of the [[BT Group]] in 2013 to replace [[Ian Livingston]] who was ennobled to join the government as Baron Livingston of Parkhead and [[Minister of State for Trade and Investment]].<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/bt-chief-ian-livingston-quits-to-join-coalition-government-as-gavin-patterson-is-brought-in-8665942.html |title=BT chief Ian Livingston quits to join Coalition Government as Gavin Patterson is brought in |last=Ashton |first=James |date=20 June 2013 |journal=[[The Independent]]}}</ref>
In August 2013, he was ranked as number 26 in ''[[The Guardian]]'''s Media 100 2013 – a listing of "the most powerful people in television, radio, newspapers, magazines, digital media, media business, advertising, marketing and PR"; it was his first appearance in this list.<ref name="guardian26">{{citation |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/sep/01/gavin-patterson-mediaguardian-100-2013 |department=Media Guardian 100 2013 |title=26. Gavin Patterson |date=1 September 2013 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref> In December 2013, ''[[Computer Weekly]]'' ranked him as number 8 in its UKtech50 for 2013 — "the most influential people in UK IT".<ref name="CW50">{{citation |url=http://www.computerweekly.com/photostory/2240210216/UKtech50-2013-the-most-influential-people-in-UK-IT/8/8-Gavin-Patterson-CEO-BT |title=8. Gavin Patterson, CEO, BT |date=4 December 2013 |department=UKtech50 2013 – the most influential people in UK IT |journal=[[Computer Weekly]]}}</ref>
He was BT's representative on the [[Confederation of British Industry]] (CBI)'s Climate Change Board,<ref name="CBIClimateChange">{{citation |url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/about_us/management/trustees/gavin_patterson.aspx |title=Trustee Gavin Patterson}}</ref> 2008-[2013], and joined the [[World Business Council for Sustainable Development]] (WBCSD)'s Executive Committee<ref name="WBCSDExCo">{{citation |url=http://www.wbcsd.org/about/organization/governance.aspx |title=WBCSD Executive Committee}}</ref> effective 1 January 2015, after the company joined WBCSD in April 2014.<ref name="BTWBCSD">{{citation |url=http://www.btplc.com/News/Articles/ShowArticle.cfm?ArticleID=36569973-C010-4385-88D5-E1D2E288810A |title=BT joins WBCSD news release}}</ref>
On 25 October 2018, it was announced that [[Philip Jansen]], the CEO of Worldpay, would succeedi him as CEO of BT, with effect from 1 January 2019, as "a change of leadership was needed".<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |title=BT appoints Worldpay's Philip Jansen as new chief executive |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-45975540 |accessdate=27 October 2018 |work=BBC |date=25 October 2018}}</ref>
==Other interests== He is a fellow of the [[Marketing Society]] and a member of the [[Thirty Club]] for advertising professionals.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=43473256&ticker=BT |title=Executive Profile: Gavin E. Patterson |publisher=Bloomberg Businessweek }}</ref> He was appointed president of the [[Advertising Association]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.adassoc.org.uk/Council|title=Council |publisher=The Advertising Association}}</ref> He is a non-executive director of [[British Airways]],<ref>Gavin Echlin Patterson works at BRITISH AIRWAYS PLC since 01 February 2011 currently as a Director - http://www.cbetta.com/director/gavin-echlin-patterson-3</ref> a trustee of the [[British Museum]], and is on the board of [[Cambridge Judge Business School]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/about_us/management/trustees/gavin_patterson.aspx |title=Trustee: Mr Gavin Patterson |publisher=The British Museum}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=http://www.btplc.com/news/articles/showarticle.cfm?articleid=%7B556af8fe-c538-4060-b803-2e4b5ee5ec3f%7D |date=19 June 2013 |title=Gavin Patterson to be appointed chief executive of BT Group |publisher=BT plc}}</ref>
==Personal life== His wife, Karen, is a fashion designer who worked for [[Donna Karan]].<ref name=FT/><ref name=TiM>{{citation |url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/markets/article-1619280/Sunday-Interview-Gavin-Patterson-BT.html |title=Sunday Interview: Gavin Patterson, BT |author=Simon Fluendy |date=21 January 2008 |publisher=This is Money}}</ref> The couple have four children and now live in Surrey.<ref name=TiM/>
He has supported [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool Football Club]] since his early years in nearby Warrington.<ref name=FT>{{citation |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/c563c2c8-4d50-11e3-bf32-00144feabdc0.html?siteedition=uk#axzz2pJo5RVLs |journal=[[Financial Times]] |title=Gavin Patterson: Betting big against Murdoch |author=Daniel Thomas |date=15 November 2013}}</ref>

{{Infobox building | name = Gold Spike | logo = | logo_size = | image = Goldspike 2009.jpg | image_size = | image_caption = Gold Spike shortly after its extensive remodeling in 2009 | building_type = Residential | location = [[Las Vegas, Nevada]] | address = 217 Las Vegas Blvd North | opening_date = 1976 | former_names = Rendezvous, Gold Spike Hotel & Casino | date_closed = | theme = | owner = [[Tony Hsieh]] | management = | architect = | rooms = 162 | shows = | attractions = | renovation_date = 2008-2010, 2013 | number_of_restaurants = Golden Grille | website = http://www.goldspike.com/ }} {{Infobox casino |name= Gold Spike Hotel & Casino |logo= |logo_size=200 |image= |image_size=250px |image_caption=Bellagio |pushpin_map=Nevada#USA |coordinates = {{coord|36.1710|-115.1405|format=dms|region:US-NV_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |address= 217 Las Vegas Blvd North |location=[[Las Vegas, Nevada]] |date_opened= 1976 |names_pre= Rendezvous |date_closed=April 14, 2013 |casino_type=Land-based |theme= |owner=[[The Siegel Group]] |architect=[[Jon Jerde]], DeRuyter Butler and Atlandia Design |rooms=112 |space_gaming={{convert|6000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} |license_holder=[[Golden Gaming]] |shows= |attractions= |notable_restaurants= Golden Grille |renovations=2004, 2006, 2011 |website= }} '''Gold Spike''' (formerly '''Gold Spike Hotel & Casino''') is a bar, lounge, residential building, and former [[boutique hotel|boutique]] 112-room,<ref name="lasvegassun1">{{cite web|last=Hansel |first=Mark |url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2009/feb/13/transformation-downtowns-gold-spike/ |title=The transformation of downtown’s Gold Spike - Las Vegas Sun News |publisher=Lasvegassun.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-21}}</ref> seven floor hotel. It is connected with the '''Oasis at the Gold Spike''', a 50-room three floor hotel located in [[downtown Las Vegas]]. It was owned by entrepreneur [[Tony Hsieh]] and his Downtown Project, having bought it from [[The Siegel Group]]; and the casino was operated by [[Golden Gaming]].
Hsieh closed the casino on April 14, 2013.<ref name=spillman /> After a three-week remodel, Gold Spike re-opened the casino as a restaurant and bar on May 6, 2013. The hotel portion of the building was recently converted into permanent and temporary workforce housing for Downtown Project, entrepreneurs, and Zappos; Oasis hotel is a separate building on the same property.<ref>http://recode.net/2014/09/30/the-gold-spike-welcome-to-your-entrepreneur-dorm/</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Jerry Fink |url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2013/may/03/joe-downtown-casino-less-gold-spike-opens-monday-o/ |title=Joe Downtown: Casino-less Gold Spike opens Monday; old pizza place to get new life - Las Vegas Sun News |publisher=Lasvegassun.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-21}}</ref>
==History==
===Rendezvous (1976-85)=== It originally opened in 1976 as the 112-room ''Rendezvous''. In 1983 [[Jackie Gaughan]] purchased the property after it had been closed for several months.
===Gold Spike Hotel & Casino (1985-2013)=== The Gold Spike for years has been known as an inexpensive hotel with few amenities.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/travel/la-082601nevada,0,389393.story | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=Four for the money | first=John | last=Deiner | date=August 26, 2001}}</ref>
On December 6, 2002, Gaughan agreed to sell the Gold Spike and three other casinos to [[Barrick Gaming]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.secinfo.com/dR7Km.32Eu.d.htm | title = Security and Exchange Form 8-K | author = SEC | date = December 6, 2002 }}</ref> This sale, along with several other downtown Las Vegas hotel/casinos, was completed in 2004, for a combined total of about $82 million.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C04E3DF1F3CF932A25752C1A9629C8B63 | work=The New York Times | title=Company News; Barrick Gaming Paying $31 Million For Nevada Casino | date=November 11, 2004}}</ref> Barrick Gaming Corp was in partnership with [[Tamares Group]]. After the purchase, management discontinued the table games and only offered slot machines. In a few years the property was offered for sale.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.lvrj.com/business/7331076.html | title = Tamares Group touts Gold Spike to buyers as low-cost entry to LV market | work = [[Las Vegas Review-Journal]] | date = May 4, 2007 }}</ref>
[[File:Gold Spike bar demolishing.jpg|thumb|Remodeling of the bar after its purchase by Hsieh]] On July 23, 2007, Greg Covin bought the property for $15.6 million with the intention of turning it into a boutique hotel.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.lvrj.com/business/8451752.html | title = Boutique style seen for the Gold Spike | work = [[Las Vegas Review-Journal]] | date = July 12, 2007 }}</ref>
He sold it on February 4, 2008 for $21 million to [[The Siegel Group]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.lvrj.com/business/15271306.html | title = For second time in six months Gold Spike sold | work = [[Las Vegas Review-Journal]] | date = February 4, 2008 }}</ref>
The Siegel Group set out to completely renovate the property<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.lvrj.com/business/new-owners-bring-money--optimism-to-downtown-89864307.html |title=New owners bring money, optimism to downtown | Las Vegas Review-Journal |publisher=Lvrj.com |date=2010-04-04 |accessdate=2013-09-21}}</ref> and combine it with an old and forgotten 52-room motel located next to the property. As one author wrote, the Gold Spike now has "Quartz walls, tile floors, wood accents, and new everything", making it "a very modern boutique hotel in the heart of downtown".<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/brandpublishing/travelplus/lasvegasguide/la-ss-vegas-quirky-70sinspired-hotel-brings-choice-vibes-to-downtown-20150227dto-story.html ]</ref> The first floor, containing the gaming floor, the bar, and the restaurant, was completely renovated by February 2009.<ref name="lasvegassun1"/>
By April 2010, all guest floors and the exterior of the hotel has been completely remodeled and renovated. In May 2010, the Oasis Pool opened, giving Gold Spike a swimming pool.
In April 2013, it was reported that the property's debt had been acquired by [[Tony Hsieh]]'s Downtown Project, a campaign to revitalize downtown Las Vegas.<ref>{{cite news|title=Joe Downtown: Want a room at the Gold Spike? You might try booking it through Zappos|newspaper=Las Vegas Sun|date=April 10, 2013|author=Joe Schoenmann|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2013/apr/10/joe-downtown-want-room-gold-spike-try-booking-it-t/|accessdate=2013-04-11}}</ref>
===Casino closure === Siegel then announced that it had sold the Gold Spike to the Downtown Project, and that the casino would close on April 14.<ref name=spillman>{{cite news|title=Downtown Project buys Gold Spike, casino to close on Sunday|newspaper=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=April 11, 2013|author=Benjamin Spillman|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/casinos-gaming/downtown-project-buys-gold-spike-casino-close-sunday|accessdate=2012-04-11}}</ref> Siegel retained rights to the Gold Spike name,<ref name=schoenmann>{{cite news|title=Joe Downtown: Downtown Project adds Gold Spike to its property holdings; casino to close Sunday|newspaper=Las Vegas Sun|author=Joe Schoenmann|date=April 11, 2013|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2013/apr/11/downtown-project-adds-gold-spike-its-property-port/|accessdate=2013-04-12}}</ref> and said that the company needed to dispose of smaller properties on its way to owning larger casinos on the Strip.<ref name=spillman /> Hsieh was reported to be considering several ideas for the property, including a boutique hotel, specialty retail space, or a club, but ruled out a casino, saying that he was "trying to help build a community".<ref name=schoenmann /> In 2014, Gold Spike reopened the former casino area as a bar and lounge with social games. Gold Spike renovated its top floor into a penthouse suite for the thirty-first season of the [[MTV]] television series ''[[Real World (TV series)|Real World]]'', ''[[Real World: Go Big or Go Home]]''. This suite can now be rented by the public and it is in the Gold Spike property and not The Oasis.<ref>http://www.reviewjournal.com/entertainment/tv/the-real-world-officially-returned-las-vegas-today</ref>
==Oasis at The Gold Spike== The adjacent 3-story motel was originally built in 1962 as a 57-room [[Travel Inn]] Motel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hotelbusiness.com/hb/links/news/news.asp?ID=38126 |title=Siegel Group Establishes Las Vegas ‘Boutique Chic Retreats’ Portfolio |publisher=hotelbusiness.com |date=2010-04-14 |accessdate=2013-09-21}}</ref> The property was abandoned, becoming a [[blight]] between the [[Fremont Street Experience]] and [[Las Vegas City Hall]]. The Siegel Group purchased this property in August 2007 for $5 million<ref name="autogenerated1"/> and started making plans to renovate it and reopen the property. Plans were put on hold when they purchased the neighboring Gold Spike. Finally, by April 2010, the rooms had been completely renovated<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qremodeling.com/contractors/Nevada/remodeling-in-Las_Vegas.html|title=The Las Vegas Remodeling Project|publisher=Q Remodeling Construction Group|date=2011-07-06}}</ref> and renamed "The Oasis at The Gold Spike"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegasweekly.com/news/2010/apr/13/rumor-has-it/ |title=Rumor has it |publisher=Las Vegas Weekly |date=2010-04-13 |accessdate=2013-09-21}}</ref> and connected to the Gold Spike via an outdoor lounge and walkway.<ref>[http://siegelcompanies.com/newsroom/siegel-group-brings-boutique-chic-retreats-las-vegas/ http://siegelcompanies.com/newsroom/siegel-group-brings-boutique-chic-retreats-las-vegas/]</ref> After a reconfiguration of the property, it was left with 50-rooms, which have been modernized and turned into bungalow suites.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hotelinteractive.com/article.aspx?articleid=16720 |title=The Siegel Group To Open Rumor Hotel In June |publisher=Hotelinteractive.com |date=2010-04-14 |accessdate=2013-09-21}}</ref>
The Oasis at the Gold Spike had the distinction of being the only [[Downtown Las Vegas|downtown]] hotel with a [[Las Vegas Boulevard|Las Vegas Blvd.]] address.<ref>[http://lasvegas.informermg.com/2013/04/13/growing-pains-gold-spike-hotel-and-casino-to-close-on-sunday-making-room-for-redevelopment/ ]</ref> In May 2010, the City of Las Vegas changed the entire Gold Spike property to this address.

'''Gonzalo Brockmann''' is a Mexican business executive. He has served as president of [[Best Western Hotel]]s of [[Mexico]], [[Central America]] and [[Ecuador]] since 1985. Prior to that he was president of Hostales de América.
He has held different positions in the "''Mexican Association of Hotels and Motels''" in [[Mexico City]], the "''National Chamber of Commercial Chambers''", and the [[Young Presidents' Organization]].
Brockmann holds an [[MBA]] degree from the [[University of Texas]] and a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in [[Administration (business)|Administration]] from the [[Universidad Anáhuac]] in Mexico City.

[[File:Aguinis1.jpg|thumb|Herman Aguinis, Ph.D.]] {{Infobox writer | name = Herman Aguinis | image = | image_size = | alt = | birth_name = Herman Aguinis | birth_date = 1966 | birth_place = [[Río Cuarto, Córdoba]], [[Argentina]] | occupation = {{hlist|Researcher|Professor|Author}} | honorific_suffix = Ph.D. | language = {{hlist|English|Spanish|French}} | residence = [[Washington, D.C.]] U.S.A. | subject = {{hlist|Talent & performance management|Star performers|Corporate social responsibility|Organizational research methods}} | relatives = [[Marcos Aguinis]] | notableworks = {{hlist|Performance Management (2019)|Applied Psychology in Talent Management (2019)|Regression Analysis for Categorical Moderators (2004)|Opening the Black Box of Editorship (2008)|Test-Score Banding in Human Resource Selection (2004)}} | awards = {{hlist| Losey Award by SHRM Foundation for lifetime achievement in human resource research|Academy of Management (AOM) Research Methods Division Distinguished Career Award for lifetime contributions|AOM Practice Impact Award for lifetime impact on policy making and managerial and organizational practices}} | spouse = Heidi Roth-Aguinis, Ph.D. | children = 2 daughters | website = {{URL|http://www.hermaguinis.com/}}
}}'''Herman Aguinis''' (born 1966) is a researcher and professor of Organizational Behavior and Human Resource Management. He is the Avram Tucker Distinguished Scholar and Professor of Management at the [[George Washington University School of Business]] in Washington, D.C.<ref>Faculty Directory, http://business.gwu.edu/profiles/herman-aguinis/</ref> He has been elected for the five-year presidency track of the [[Academy of Management]] (AOM) and is serving as AOM Program Chair Elect & Vice President Elect, Program Chair & Vice President, President Elect, President, and Past President during 2018-2023.<ref>2018 Board of Governors Election Results, http://aom.org/About-AOM/Governance/2018-Board-of-Governors-Election-Results.aspx</ref> Prior to moving to Washington D.C. in 2016, he was the John F. Mee Chair of Management and the Founding Director of the Institute for Global Organizational Effectiveness in the [[Kelley School of Business]] at [[Indiana University]].
==Personal and professional background== Herman Aguinis was born in [[Rio Cuarto, Cordoba]] ([[Argentina]]). He is the son of the Argentine author [[Marcos Aguinis]] and University of Buenos Aires School of Law professor Ana Maria "Marita" Aguinis (deceased).<ref>Books by professor Ana Maria "Marita" Aguinis (deceased), https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=dp_byline_sr_book_1?ie=UTF8&text=Ana+Maria+M.+de+Aguinis&search-alias=books&field-author=Ana+Maria+M.+de+Aguinis&sort=relevancerank</ref> He attended high school at the [[Colegio Nacional de Buenos Aires]]<ref>Aguinis, H. (2006). From Río Cuarto to Denver. The Industrial-Organizational Psychologist, 43(4), 57-61.</ref> before receiving a Bachelors’ and master's degree in psychology from the [[University of Buenos Aires]]. He spent part of his high school years in New York City, but following his schooling in Argentina, he moved to the United States permanently to study Industrial and Organizational Psychology, earning a Master’s and a PhD degree from the [[University at Albany, State University of New York]] in 1993.
His research, teaching, and consulting are about the acquisition and deployment of talent in organizations and organizational research methods. He has written extensively on the topics of star performance, corporate social responsibility, domestic and international diversity, leadership, staffing, training and development, performance management, and innovative methodological approaches for developing and testing theories. His research has been featured by the media worldwide, including most recently the Wall Street Journal,<ref>CEO Pay and Performance Often Don’t Match Up, https://www.wsj.com/articles/ceo-pay-and-performance-dont-match-up-1526299200?ns=prod/accounts-wsj</ref> and in U.S. Supreme Court cases.<ref>RICCI v. DESTEFANO, https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/crt/legacy/2010/12/28/ricci_sctdec.pdf</ref> He served as Editor-in-Chief of [[Organizational Research Methods]] (2005-2007) and has served or serves on the editorial board of 26 journals including [[Journal of Applied Psychology]], [[Personnel Psychology (journal)]], [[Journal of Management]], and [[Journal of International Business Studies]].<ref>Editorships and Editorial Board Memberships, http://www.hermanaguinis.com/sactive.htm#ProfessionReviewer</ref>
He has delivered more than 260 keynote addresses and presentations at professional conferences,<ref>Keynote Addresses & Presentations at Professional Meetings, http://hermanaguinis.com/conf.html</ref> delivered about 130 invited presentations in all seven continents except for Antarctica,<ref>Invited Presentations, http://hermanaguinis.com/invitedpresentations.html</ref> and raised about $5MM for his research and teaching endeavors from private foundations and federal sources (e.g., National Science Foundation).<ref>Understanding the Gender Performance Gap among Star Performers in STEM Fields, https://www.nsf.gov/awardsearch/showAward?AWD_ID=1643075</ref>
==Awards and honors== His research has placed him as one of the most influential and prolific contemporary management professors in the world.<ref>Podsakoff, P. M., MacKenzie, S. B., Podsakoff, N. P., & Bachrach, D. G. 2008. Scholarly influence in the field of management: A bibliometric analysis of the determinants of university and author impact in the management literature in the past quarter century. Journal of Management, 34: 641-720. The following article ranked him as the #5 most published author in JOM: Van Fleet, D. D., & Bedeian, A. G. 2016. The Journal of Management’s first 40 years: A look back. Journal of Management, 42, 349-356.</ref><ref>Aguinis, H., Suarez-González, I., Lannelongue, G., & Joo, H. 2012. Scholarly impact revisited. Academy of Management Perspectives, 26(2): 105-132.</ref><ref>Aguinis, H., Ramani, R. S., Campbell, P. K., Bernal-Turnes, P., Drewry, J. M., & Edgerton, B. T. 2017. Most frequently cited sources, articles, and authors in industrial-organizational psychology textbooks: Implications for the science-practice divide, scholarly impact, and the future of the field. Industrial and Organizational Psychology: Perspectives on Science and Practice, 10: 507-557.</ref> As of November 2018, he is among the world’s 96 most impactful researchers in economics and business as demonstrated by production of multiple highly cited papers that rank in the top 1% by citations for field and year in Web of Science (2006-2016). <ref>Highly Cited Researchers 2018. https://hcr.clarivate.com/</ref> An article published in August 2018 ranked him among the top 1% of the top 1% (i.e., #34 out of about 500,000) most highly cited researchers in the fields of economics and business based on articles published between 2004 and 2015 according to the Web of Science Essential Science Indicators database.<ref>Zhang, N., Wan, S., Wang, P. et al. Scientometrics (2018). https://doi.org/10.1007/s11192-018-2786-7</ref> His work has received more than 23,000 Google Scholar citations,<ref>See [https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=VbMNUXoAAAAJ&hl=en https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=VbMNUXoAAAAJ&hl=en] for his Google Scholar profile</ref> and he has more than 26,000 LinkedIn followers.<ref>https://www.linkedin.com/in/herman-aguinis-66417016/</ref>
He is a fellow of the [[Academy of Management]] (and also served as Deputy Dean of the Academy of Management Fellows until August 2018),<ref>Fellows Group of the Academy of Management, http://aom.org/fellows.aspx</ref> [[American Psychological Association]], [[Society for Industrial and Organizational Psychology]], and [[Association for Psychological Science]] and has received many awards such as:
* Losey Award by the Society for Human Resource Management Foundation for lifetime achievement in human resource research<ref>Herman Aguinis Named 2017 Losey Research Award Winner, https://www.shrm.org/hr-today/news/hr-news/Pages/Herman-Aguinis-Named-2017-Losey-Research-Award-Winner.aspx</ref> * Academy of Management Research Methods Division Distinguished Career Award for lifetime contributions<ref> Award Winners, http://rmdiv.org/?page_id=20</ref> * Academy of Management Practice Theme Committee Scholar Practice Impact Award recognizing an outstanding scholar who has affected policy making and managerial and organizational practices<ref>PTC Awards and Panels of Judges, http://www.ptc-aom.com/index.php/awards/aom-ptc-practice-impact-award</ref> * Academy of Management Entrepreneurship Division IDEA Thought Leader Award<ref> IDEA Thought Leader Awards, https://ent.aom.org/awards</ref> * Academy of Management Research Methods Division Robert McDonald Advancement of Organizational Research Methodology Award * Six best article of the year awards from the journals ''Personnel Psychology'', ''Journal of Management'', ''Journal of Organizational Behavior'' (twice), ''Academy of Management Perspectives'', and ''Organizational Research Methods''.<ref>http://www.hermanaguinis.com/</ref>
==Selected publications== Herman Aguinis is the author of several published books and more than 150 peer-reviewed journal articles.<ref>See [http://www.hermanaguinis.com/pubs.html http://www.hermanaguinis.com/pubs.html] for a full listing of published works by Herman Aguinis</ref>
===Books=== * Aguinis, H. 2019. ''Performance management'' (4th ed.). Chicago, IL: Chicago Business Press. {{ISBN|978-0-9988140-8-7}}. * Cascio, W.F., & Aguinis, H. 2019. ''Applied psychology in talent management'' (8th ed.). Thousand Oaks, CA: SAGE. {{ISBN|9781506375915}}. * Aguinis, H. 2004. ''Regression analysis for categorical moderators''. New York, NY: Guilford. {{ISBN|1572309695}}. * Baruch, Y., Konrad, A.M., Aguinis, H., & Starbuck, W.H. (Eds.). 2008. ''Opening the black box of editorship''. New York, NY: Palgrave-Macmillan. {{ISBN|0230013600}}. * Aguinis, H. (Ed.). 2004. ''Test-score banding in human resource selection: Legal, technical, and societal issues''. Westport, CT: Praeger. {{ISBN|1567205208}}.
===Journal articles=== * Aguinis, H., & Glavas, A. in press. On corporate social responsibility, sensemaking, and the search for meaningfulness through work. ''Journal of Management.'' doi: 10.1177/0149206317691575 * Aguinis, H., Ji, Y. H., & Joo, H. in press. Gender productivity gap among star performers in STEM and other scientific fields. ''Journal of Applied Psychology.'' doi: 10.1037/apl0000331. * Aguinis, H., Ramani, R. S., & Alabduljader, N. 2018. What you see is what you get? Enhancing methodological transparency in management research. ''Academy of Management Annals'', 12: 83-110. * Aguinis, H., & O’Boyle, E. 2014. Star performers in twenty-first-century organizations. ''Personnel Psychology'', 67: 313-350. * Aguinis, H., Joo, H., & Gottfredson, R. K. 2011. Why we hate performance management—and why we should love it. ''Business Horizons'', 54: 503-507.

{{Contract law}} In [[contract law]], an '''illusory promise''' is one that courts will not enforce. This is in contrast with a [[contract]], which is a promise that courts will enforce. A promise may be illusory for a number of reasons. In [[common law]] countries this usually results from failure or lack of [[consideration]] (see also [[consideration under English law]]).
Illusory promises are so named because they merely hold the illusion of contract. For example, a promise of the form, "I will give you ten dollars if I feel like it," is purely illusory and will not be enforced as a contract.
It is a general principle of contract law that courts should err on the side of enforcing contracts.<ref>Kirby J in ''Biotechnology Australia Pty Ltd v Pace'' (1988) 15 NSWLR 130</ref> Parties entering into the arrangement presumably had the intention of forming an enforceable contract, and so courts generally attempt to follow this intention.<ref>See ''Portland Gasoline Co. v. Superior Marketing Co., 150 Tex. 533, 243 S.W.2d 823, 824, (1951''), overruled on other grounds by ''Northern Natural Gas Co. v. Conoco, Inc., 986 S.W.2d. 603 (Tex. 1998)''.</ref>
A promise conditioned upon an event within the promisor's control is not illusory if the promisor also "impliedly promises to make reasonable effort to bring the event about or to use good faith and honest judgment in determining whether or not it has in fact occurred."<ref>1 Corbin on Contracts, s 149, at 659.</ref>
Methods of finding potentially illusory contracts enforceable include: * Implied-in-law "good faith" terms * Implied-in-fact terms * Bargaining for a chance
==Implied-in-law "good faith" terms== Many contracts include "satisfaction clauses", in which a promisor can refuse to pay if he isn't subjectively satisfied with the promisee's performance. Strictly speaking, this is an illusory promise, since the promisor has no actual legal burden to pay if he chooses not to. However, courts will generally imply in law that the promisor must act in good faith and reject the deal only if he is genuinely dissatisfied. As another example, if a contract promises a promisee a certain percentage of the proceeds of a promisor's business activities, this is illusory, since the promisor doesn't have to do anything: any percentage of zero is zero. However, courts may find that the promisor made an implied promise to use reasonable efforts to try to make money, and cite him for breach of contract if he does absolutely nothing.<ref>See ''[[Wood v. Lucy, Lady Duff-Gordon]]'', 222 N.Y. 88, 118 N.E. 214 (1917).</ref> The U.C.C. in contracts exclusive to both sides requires "best efforts" in such contracts. This may be read to be the same as a good faith effort, but is seen by some courts as a higher duty.
==Implied-in-fact terms== Judges will often infer terms into the contract that the parties did not explicitly cite. For instance, in the "satisfaction clause" case, judges might infer that the parties intended a "reasonableness test" - that the clause could be satisfied if a reasonable person would be satisfied by the promisee's performance, regardless of whether the promisor himself asserts he is satisfied. (This interpretation is often used in cases in which a performance can be objectively evaluated, such as with the construction of a warehouse; the implied-in-law interpretation above is preferred where satisfaction is more subjective, as with the painting of a portrait.)
==Bargaining for a chance== Many judges{{who|date=February 2011}} would consider the "bargaining for a percentage of the proceeds" example above an enforceable contract, even without an implied-in-fact or implied-in-law good faith term. They would view the opportunity to enter into a business relationship to itself be acceptable consideration. Put differently, the mere possibility that the promisor would do business is a valuable product of the bargain even if he does not do anything. Of course, if the promisor entered into the relationship purely with the intent of fraudulently harming the promisee, he could be cited for fraud or bad faith principles that apply to all contracts.
==Changes to a "contract" without notification== Some websites' "terms and conditions" may be deemed an illusory contract and unenforceable if the language can be changed at any time by the company without notifying users and giving them a chance to accept the new changes.<ref>[[Harris v. Blockbuster Inc.]], No. 09-cv-217 (N.D. Tex. April 15, 2009)</ref><ref>Goldman, Eric. [https://www.forbes.com/sites/ericgoldman/2012/10/10/how-zappos-user-agreement-failed-in-court-and-left-zappos-legally-naked/ How Zappos' User Agreement Failed In Court and Left Zappos Legally Naked], ''Forbes.com'', Oct. 10, 2012.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox person | name = Jack Bendat | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1925|5|6|df=y}} | birth_place = [[United States]] | nationality = [[Australians|Australian]] | education = | occupation = [[Businessperson|Businessman]] | employer = | credits = | spouse = Eleanor Bendat }}
'''Jack Bendat''' (born 6 May 1925) is an American-born Australian [[businessperson|businessman]] and owner of the [[Perth Wildcats]] basketball team. He was previously involved in construction and media businesses with longtime partner [[Kerry Stokes]], but is now involved in philanthropic and sporting interests.
== Biography == === Early life === Jack Bendat was born in the United States and migrated with his family from [[California]] to [[Perth]] in 1966.<ref name="abc-interview">{{cite interview | title=Who are you? Jack Bendat | date=January 2012 | accessdate=3 June 2015 | last=Hutchison | first=Geoff | subjectlink=Jack Bendat | interviewer=Geoff Hutchison | work=Mornings with Geoff Hutchison | publisher=720 ABC Perth | url=http://mpegmedia.abc.net.au/local/perth/201201/r882388_8752635.mp3}}</ref>
=== Career === Bendat, along with partners [[Kerry Stokes]] and Kevin Merifield, were involved in the development of shopping centres in [[Perth]] and regional [[Western Australia]]. Bendat appeared at #70 on BRW's 2014 Rich List.<ref name="brw-2014">{{cite news | url=http://www.brw.com.au/p/lists/rich-200/2014/brw_rich_list_jack_bendat_sWmcYtSYuZXETNDuGN2FNM | title=BRW Rich 200 list 2014: 70. Jack Bendat | work=BRW. | date=27 June 2014 | accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref>
Bendat's business accomplishments include building Bunbury Plaza, one of the first country shopping centres in Western Australia, and establishing country media service GWN (now [[GWN7]]). He went on to work on development of 11 shopping centres around Western Australia.<ref name="wilcats-givingback">{{cite web | url=http://www.wildcats.com.au/article/id/5hapv494i7x31rdfoleynovvt | title=Dr Bendat focuses on giving back to WA | publisher=Perth Wildcats | date=25 January 2012 | accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref>
=== Personal life === Bendat is married and has two children.
=== Philanthropy === One of Bendat's major contributions has been the Bendat Family Comprehensive Cancer Centre at the [[St John of God Subiaco Hospital]]. Bendat's contribution to the community was recognised as WA Citizen of the Year in 2002.<ref name="west-bigredarmy">{{cite news | url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/a/16461564/bendat-builds-big-red-army/ | title=Bendat builds big red army | work=The West Australian | date=28 March 2013 | accessdate=3 June 2015 | author=Butler, Steve}}</ref> Bendat was also made a member of the Order of Australia in 2009.<ref name="watoday-honours">{{cite news | url=http://www.watoday.com.au/wa-news/48-wa-residents-honoured-20090607-by9y | title=48 WA residents honoured | work=WA Today | date=8 June 2009 | accessdate=3 June 2015 |author1=Clarke, Tim |author2=Sonti, Chalpat }}</ref>
=== Sporting Interests === Bendat bought the [[Perth Wildcats]] [[basketball]] club in 2007.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.afr.com/business/wildcats-a-slam-dunk-for-jack-bendat-at-89-20140330-ix9t3 | title=Wildcats: a slam dunk for Jack Bendat at 89 | work=Australian Financial Review | date=31 May 2014 | accessdate=3 June 2015}}{{subscription needed}}</ref> In his time as owner, the club has won four NBL championships: 2009–10, 2013–14 and 2015–16, 2016–17 and expanded significantly, drawing larger crowds to their new home court at RAC Arena. In April 2015, Bendat purchased the licence for the Perth WNBL team in the West Coast Waves and renamed them the [[Perth Lynx]], and the following month, on his 90th Birthday, the [[WA Basketball Centre]] was renamed the ''Bendat Basketball Centre'' in his honour.<ref name="pn-bendatbasketballcentre">{{cite news | url=http://www.perthnow.com.au/sport/basketball/bendat-basketball-centre-the-new-name-for-was-main-facility-named-after-jack-bendat/story-fnhq5y0s-1227338638397 | title=Bendat Basketball Centre the new name for WA’s main facility, named after Jack Bendat | work=PerthNow | date=6 May 2015 | accessdate=3 June 2015 | author=Robinson, Chris}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Perth Wildcats}}

{{other people|James Banks}} {{Infobox engineer |image = |image_width = |caption = |name = James Arthur Banks |nationality = [[Scotland|Scottish]] |birth_date = 1897 |birth_place = [[Glasgow]] |death_date = 1 December 1967 (aged 67) |death_place = |education = |spouse = |parents = |children = |discipline = [[Civil engineering|Civil]] |institutions = [[Institution of Civil Engineers]] (president),
[[Royal Society of Edinburgh]] (Fellow) |practice_name = |significant_projects = |significant_design = |significant_advance = |significant_awards = }} [[File:ICE editathon - One Great George Street - 19 July 2013 20 Plaque listing presidents (1 of 2 closeup).jpg|thumb|Banks' name on the list of [[Institution of Civil Engineers]] presidents, at their [[One Great George Street]] headquarters]] '''James Arthur Banks''' {{post-nominals|CVO|OBE|FRSE}} (1897 – 1 December 1967) was a [[Scotland|Scottish]] [[civil engineer]].[http://www.royalsoced.org.uk/fellowship/all_fellows.pdf Royal Society of Edinburgh list of fellows] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828135318/http://www.royalsoced.org.uk/fellowship/all_fellows.pdf |date=28 August 2008 }} Banks was born in [[Glasgow]] in 1897. He attended Woodside Higher Grade School in [[Glasgow]]. During [[World War I]] he served in the Royal Marine Engineers, from 1914 to 1918.http://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp1.pdf He initially trained as a structural engineer and then joined [[Babtie, Shaw and Morton]] in 1921 to train as a civil engineer.Babtie 1895-1995: A Century of Achievement. Babtie Group. 1995. p66 He worked in England and the USA and returned to Babtie, Shaw and Morton in 1929. His speciality was the design and construction of dams for water supply and power generation, commencing with [[Afton Reservoir]]. He became a partner of the firm in 1931 and was senior partner from 1940 to 1966. He was appointed a [[Member of the Order of the British Empire]] in 1944.[http://www.iceknowledge.com/ArticleView.aspx?doi=10.1680/iicep.1965.9206 ICE biography] He was appointed an officer of the same order in the [[New Year Honours]] of 1947 and a [[Commander of the Royal Victorian Order]] on 31 May 1963.{{London Gazette|issue=37835|page=19|supp=y|date=31 December 1946}}{{London Gazette|issue=43010|page=5|supp=y|date=31 May 1963}} From 1961 Banks was chairman of the International Commission on Large Dams and was Consulting Engineer to [[Queen Elizabeth II]] for the [[Balmoral Castle|Balmoral Estate]] and a member of the Court of the [[University of Strathclyde]]. He served as president of the [[Institution of Civil Engineers]] from November 1965 to November 1966 and was elected a [[Fellow#Learned or professional societies|Fellow]] of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]] on 6 March 1967.{{Cite book | last = Watson | first = Garth | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = The Civils | publisher = Thomas Telford | year = 1988 | location = | pages = 254 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-7277-0392-7}} He died on 1 December 1967. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{S-start}} {{s-npo|pro}} {{S-bef|before=[[Robert Wynne-Edwards]]}} {{S-ttl|title=[[List of Presidents of the Institution of Civil Engineers|President]] of the [[Institution of Civil Engineers]] |years=November 1965 – November 1966}} {{S-aft|after=[[Ralph Freeman (son)|Ralph Freeman]]}} {{end}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Banks, James Arthur}} [[Category:1897 births]] [[Category:1967 deaths]] [[Category:Scottish civil engineers]] [[Category:Presidents of the Institution of Civil Engineers]] [[Category:People from Glasgow]] [[Category:Officers of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Commanders of the Royal Victorian Order]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Hydraulic engineers]] [[Category:People associated with the University of Strathclyde]] [[Category:Scottish businesspeople]] {{Scotland-engineer-stub}} {{Civil-engineering-stub}}

{{Infobox person |name = José Ferré |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = José Antonio Ferré Aguayo |birth_date = {{birth date|1902|9|12}} |birth_place = [[Ponce, Puerto Rico]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1990|9|15|1902|9|12}} |death_place = [[Puerto Rico]] |death_cause = |resting_place = |nationality = [[Puerto Rican people|Puerto Rican]] |other_names = |education = |employer = |occupation = Businessman |title = |parents = Antonio Ferré and Mary Aguayo }}
'''José Antonio Ferré Aguayo''' (September 12, 1902 – September 15, 1990) was a [[Puerto Rican people|Puerto Rican]] businessman, industrialist and government official. He was a brother of [[Luis A. Ferré|Luis Ferré]], who served as [[Governor of Puerto Rico]], and [[Isolina Ferré]], the "[[Mother Teresa]] of Puerto Rico". Ferré was also the father of [[Maurice Ferré]], a former six-term mayor of [[Miami, Florida]].<ref>{{cite book | title=Hispanics in American Politics: The Search for Political Power | first=Maurilio E. | last=Vigil | year=1987 | page=102 | chapter=Hispanics in Local Office- State and Local Levels}}</ref>
==Early life and education==
Ferré was born in Ponce and the son of Cuban born Antonio Ferré Bacallao.<ref name="Sarasota"/> After attending [[Morristown-Beard School#History|Morristown-School]] (now Morristown-Beard School) in [[Morristown, New Jersey]], he earned his bachelor's degree in business administration at [[Boston University]] in [[Boston, Massachusetts]] in 1924.<ref name="congressional record">{{USCongRec|1990|E3220}}</ref> Ferré later served on the Board of Trustees of the school alongside [[Edward Kennedy]].<ref>{{cite news | newspaper=The New York Times | title=Boston U Names a Kennedy | date=21 October 1961}} "Edward M. Kennedy, youngest brother of President Kennedy, was one of three persons elected today to the Board of Trustees of Boston University. Other elected were Stephen P. Mugar of Belmont, President of the Star Market Company, and Jose A. Ferre, industrialist."</ref> He earned his master's degree in business administration from the [[University of Miami]].<ref name="congressional record"/>
==Industrial development==
During the years following [[World War II]], Ferré grew his wealth by purchasing bankrupt glass, cement, and carton factories. At one point, his family empire owned 80 corporations in Puerto Rico, the United States, Venezuela, and Panama.<ref name="Sarasota">{{cite news | newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune | title=Jose Antonio Ferre Aguayo | date=19 September 1990}}</ref>
In 1965, Ferré's real estate company, the Ferré Florida Corporation, financed the construction of the 30-story [[New World Tower]] in the [[Downtown Miami#Central business district ("Downtown")|Central Business District]] in Miami. At the time, the building, which cost $6 million to construct, stood as the tallest in Florida.<ref>{{cite news | newspaper=The New York Times | title=30-Story Miami Building Will Be Tallest in Florida | date=27 November 1963}}</ref> Its construction represented part of a broader effort to revitalize Miami.<ref>{{cite news | newspaper=The New York Times | title=MIAMI REVERSES TREND OF DOWNTOWN DECAY; Enormous Project | date=November 3, 1987}}</ref>
==Legacy==
In 1990, U.S. Representative [[Ileana Ros-Lehtinen]] from [[Florida's 27th congressional district]] honored the legacy and impact of Ferré during remarks on the floor of the [[U.S. House of Representatives]]. The tribute recognized Ferré's vision and industrial pursuits.<ref name="congressional record"/>

'''Lev Khasis''' (Лев Аронович Хасис; born 5 June 1966, in [[Samara, Russia|Kuybyshev]], now Samara, [[RSFSR]], [[USSR]]) was the first [[CEO]] of the [[X5 Retail Group]] (2006-2011). Vice-Chairman of [[Jet.com]], Inc until the company was acquired by Walmart in September 2016, Board member of Boxed.com, Board Member of LendingHome.com since February 2017. Chairman of the board of Evotor.ru since February 2017. Chairman of the board of DocDoc.ru
COO and First deputy CEO of [[Sberbank]] since 2013.
== Education == In 1989 he graduated from [[Kuybyshev Aviation Institute]], the aircraft engineering faculty. In 1995 he graduated from banking faculty of the Moscow Financial Academy. In 2001 he earned a Master of Law at [[Saint Petersburg University]] of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Russia, Law School.
In July 2006 he received his Ph.D in Economics from the Institute for System Analysis at the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.samru.ru/bisnes/elit/11160.html |title=ЛЕВ ХАСИС: В Самаре люди спокойнее и добрее… |publisher=Samru.ru |date= |accessdate=2012-05-31}}</ref>
==Career== He served in various roles in business and the academy.
*1989—1990 — Head of the Department of International Affairs of Kuybyshev Aviation Institute *1991—1993 — general director of JSC "Samarsky Trading House" *1993—1994 — Samara branch general manager of «[[Avtovazbank]]» *1995—1999 — president, chairman of the board of directors of OJSC «[[Aviacor]]» Corporation *1996—1998 — vice-president of OJSC «[[Alfa-Bank]]» *Since 1999 — member of the Board of Directors of ZAO Trading House «[[Perekrestok (supermarket chain)|Supermarkets chain Perekrestok]]» *2001—2005 — Chairman of the Board of Directors of Trading House «[[TsUM]]» and Trading House «[[GUM (department store)|GUM]] (department store)» *2002 — 2006 - Chairman of the Board of Directors of Trading House «[[Perekrestok (supermarket chain)|Supermarkets chain Perekrestok]]l]]» *2006 - 2011 — Chief Executive Officer ([[CEO]]) of [[X5 Retail Group]] *2007 — 2011 Chairman of Presidium of the [[Association of Retailers of Russia]] (AKORT) *2005 — 2014 member of the Board of Directors of "[[Transaero]]" Airlines *2011 - 2012 Senior Vice-President and Chief Leverage Officer at [[Wal-Mart Stores Inc]] *2012-2013 CEO&President New Formats at [[Walmart Stores Inc]] *2015-2016 Vice-Chairman of [[Jet.com]], Inc . *Since 2013 COO&First Deputy CEO at [[Sberbank]]
